zuul/manager/__init__.py.message: To me, "parent" means git parent and this could be either git or depends-on (or same-topic) changes, so I think that might be unintentionally misleading.
Would this be more clear if it said "Parent changes {clist} are needed."?

Should this message say "Changes {clist} in cycle can not be merged." That way it is clear that it may be a child change that isn't mergeable? At least for me I always look to parents but with cycles it could be the other direction.

That would work too I think -- but also note that on dep cycles, we add a bit to the message that says "Related changes: ..." so users can see the cycle and that's an extra indication that it is a cycle.  So I think I was trying to keep this message as brief as possible.  But I'm happy to add the extra words if it makes it clearer.

zuul/reporter/__init__.py.message:
Is item.bundle.cannot_merge always either str or None? In that case can we simplify this block to something like:

  if item.bundle.cannot_merge:
      msg = 'This change is part of a bundle that can not merge.\n'
      msg += '\n' + item.bundle.cannot_merge + '\n'
      
Is this existing check for backward compatibility with code that serialized item info prior to this change?

Two things: One: I'm trying to use the boolean methods here because they really help a lot when searching the code for decisions based on these values.  Two (and more important): bundle can be None, so the accessor method helps check that dereference.

And yes, cannot_merge was previously a boolean and is now a nullable string, so the type check is for backwards compat.
Re the above comment should this use wasDequeuedNeedingChange()?
Also backwards compat for a boolean that is now a nullable string.
See above, is it possible for this to be a non str type?

But today the PciDevice does not depend on PciDeviceSpec. The relationship is inverted. The PciDeviceSpec knows about the PciDevice via the PciDeviceSpec.match_pci_obj(self, pci_obj: 'objects.PciDevice') call. Changing this relationship probably have a wide change surface touching the legacy codepath as well. e.g.: today the value of the tags can change in the config or on the hypervisor _after_ the PciDevice is created in the DB.

So I'm reluctant to make the full move as part of this work as it might create unnecessary impact around the legacy behaviors.

    upper case, replacing any consecutive character outside of  ``[A-Z0-9_]``
    with a single '_', and  prefixing the name with ``CUSTOM_`` if not yet
    prefixed.
    
So it covers the case when the name is prefixed with custom- instead for custom_.

traits
https://github.com/openstack/os-traits/blob/master/os_traits/compute/__init__.py#L37-L40=

I would prefer to use the standard owner trait too. But unfortunately it is not enough. 

What this patch needs is a way to detect if any RP in the tree is
1) owned by nova
and
2) represents PCI device(s)

The #1) can be indicated with the standard owner trait but #2) cannot. There will be RPs in the tree with the standard owner trait that are not PCI devs, i.e. the root RP, and the MDEV RPs. The code cannot rely on the RC as RC can be anything coming form the user and can change via reboot. So nova doesn't have a list of RCs that _was_ representing a PCI devices before the current compute service reboot and therefore potential RC change in the config.

So I had to invent something. As traits are pretty free to add I went with that. 

One can argue that this code try to rely on the naming of the RPs but right now nothing prevents a project (i.e. cyborg) to start adding similar name pattern than us. Also in the future we might want to use the same name pattern for MDEV devices as well.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I don't see why this should be done. While the u' prefix is redundant in python3, it is also not deprecated in any way afaict, so I don't see a reason to touch all this code.

All strings are considered as unicode string from Python 3.

This patch drops the explicit unicode literal (u'...')
appearances from the unicode strings.

This explains *what* you are doing, it does not explain *why* this should be done. To me, there are two options:

1. Don't do this patch, leave the code as it is, since it is working perfectly well. Maybe clean things up if that code ever needs to be touched for a different reason.

2. Apply your patch.

I prefer 1., I would like to see some argument as to why you prefer 2. Also, as mentioned elsewhere, if 2. is to be done, it should be done consistently across all of opendev, which would require prior discussion with all the teams involved. Submitting such a mass of patches without this preparation isn't good style and should be avoided in general.

Ok, thank you very much for your guidance. I agree with you and I will give up this modification. In addition, I am very sorry for submitting a lot of changes without preparation. I will pay attention to it in the future. Thank you again.

It does make we worried aobut error limiting. I know you do have a patch to not error limit 529s. But does make we wonder if its something we do want before we ever use this. Especially when the `Node error limited` logs are logged at debug, so we wont see them in prod. So long as error limiting is invisible to the logs, I don't like adding something that would increase it. Worse this happened on my VSAIO where I only have 4 nodes, in prod what would happen... they'd all get palmed off further and further down the handoff stack.

I think more *transparency* in proxy error limiting would be super useful to invest in: maybe some statsd in addition to debug logging?

It's orthogonal tho, how could having NO control over a node getting error limited because of Timeouts possibly be BETTER than ops having the option to push back against a flooded storage service with 529s.  So what if a few 503s make it out to the client - we are doing that ANYWAY.

Is the name "backend rate limiting" vs. "backend load shedding" making people think this is supposed to somehow be a tool for the services to communitcate to the proxy "slow down" instead of "go away"?

Maybe instead of limiting to a "rate" it would be easier to understand if the limit was on "in-flight" - part of the reason we've seen servers get bogged down, fall over, and crap on everything is because the responses start getting SLOW and the backlog grows without bound.

There are mixed opinions on whether the proxy should error limit or not. I initially felt strongly it should not, because the time scales of error limiting vs rate limiting are very different. But I also recognise that not error limiting in the proxy results in increased backend requests as proxy keeps trying 'too busy' nodes.

There is some mitigation in that there are N to 1 proxies to backend ratelimiter, so on average each proxy will receive requests_per_second/N 529s from a 'too busy' node.

Another mitigation is to increase the rate_buffer closer to the error limit interval. In extreme, if rate_buffer == error limit interval then the proxy would be appropriately backing off (i.e. backend has stacked up 60s worth of requests and proxy error limits for 60s). But this does mean the backend stacking up 60s worth of requests.

A combination of the 2 mitigations may be the answer, but we'll need to carefully tune and learn.

FWIW, long term I'd like the proxy to grow a more sensitive error/backoff algorithm. For example, order backend nodes based on rate of 529s, with thresholds to fully error limit nodes.

> A combination of the 2 mitigations may be the answer, but we'll need to carefully tune and learn.

I think it's just as hard for me to believe "a proxy should NEVER error limit a server returning 529s"  as it is "we can't possibly USE backned ratelimits as long as the proxy might error limit"

I think this is a step we could take and improve, and the code is ready - let's ALSO improve proxy error limiting; which could in the future include deliniating not just how we handle a 507 from a 503 or a Timeout but now... a 529!
This has a +2 from clay and I and was months ago. So going to +A this one.

kk, fair enough. It's also hard to know what to tune until we have something. So I'm on board. Still would like the confirugation in the SAIO configuration, but I've gone and done that in a follow up (after reloadable config) as we might as well configure it that way in SAIO: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/842909

There are multiple code paths that call _listInstances, not all of which return the higher level objects (to be clear, we're not modifying the result, we're augmenting it), so it's best to cache at the lowest level so they all benefit.

We are caching the underlying request responses but then we perform additional modification here. Would it make sense to cache this layer instead and then cut down on the quota and such modifications?

Just to be clear. The purpose of the initramfs is to load the drivers needed to mount the rootfs. If we are not using NFSroot or similar (which require networking) then the drivers found in the initramfs for such devices *should not* be loaded and there is no "incorrect version of the driver to be used.". So this commit log is slightly posting incorrect information.

I am fine with a goal of keeping the initramfs drivers matching the ones found in the rootfs, as the project doesn't have unlimited contributors and this means 1 version of a driver being used by the project instead of 2.

Hi Mark,

My understanding is that StarlingX has had a number of out-of-tree and in-tree NIC drivers in its initramfs for a long time period, and I think there were valid reasons for those (such as PXE-booting an installation).

I admit that the initramfs being regenerated with this commit is not reused for PXE boot, but if the initramfs has a stale version of the NIC driver, then the desired version will not be loaded after the pivot to the real root file system.

All this to say, I agree that there appears to be room for improvement. Perhaps we should discuss this further in a more formal setting.

Hi Jim,

I checked our internal patch releases, and I found that all patches fall under the following categories:

1) Patch updated ice only.
2) Patch updated ice, iavf, i40e together.
3) Patch updated iavf or i40e, and did not update ice, but updated the kernel as well.
4) Patch was released before the removal of weak-modules with the following commit:
  https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/kernel/+/737079

I can go over these cases one by one:

1) ice driver has "dracut --force" in the "postun" section of its spec file, so starting with the following/next ice driver update patch, the post-uninstallation hook will ensure that dracut is called. (It looks like ice was introduced with a kernel version bump, because the kernel's in-tree ice was disabled. This takes care of the first time the ice driver was introduced.) (Another case is that the ice driver was already out-of-tree starting with the original release. In that case, a kmod-ice RPM update will call the previous version's post-uninstallation scriptlet, which will regenerate the initramfs.)

2) Since ice update is included, this is similar to (1).

3) Kernel update automatically regenerates the initramfs.

4) I had a look at the "weak-modules" script's contents on a build server running CentOS 7 and looked at the post-installation and post-uninstallation scriptlets of the i40e driver from an older patch. It looks like weak-modules automatically regenerates the initramfs when it detects that the installed/updated modules are different, and prior to commit https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/kernel/+/737079 weak-modules was included in all drivers' RPM spec files.

I think that this is a day 1 problem, at least after the removal of the weak-modules calls from the RPM scriptlets.

I agree with your concern about the package installation/update time becoming very large. dracut takes a while to run, and we should optimize this. I had mentioned in the bug report's description that we could use a different method than the approach taken by this commit; we could use file-based per-transaction triggers in the kernel package's spec file, which allow the update procedure to run dracut once per transaction. Quoting from my notes (also in the bug description):

https://bugs.launchpad.net/starlingx/+bug/1983524
```
One potential solution is for the kernel package to include an RPM file-based
transaction trigger that regenerates the initramfs for every RPM transaction
(i.e., upgrade/install/remove) that adds/removes/modifies kernel modules under
the /lib/modules/<kver> directory. This mechanism is described here:
```
https://rpm-software-management.github.io/rpm/manual/file_triggers.html

Hi Jiping,

I am not 100% sure, but this might not do what expect when we uninstall a StarlingX patch that includes a kernel package for a kernel that is currently running. Let me explain:

When uninstalling the kernel package, according to the following link, %transfiletriggerpostun might be (I am not sure) executed near the end of the transaction: https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/packaging-guidelines/Scriptlets/#ordering

However, if we are uninstalling the currently running kernel package, then this line will regenerate the initramfs, and (*maybe*) prevent the removal of the initramfs image from the /boot file system. So, there could be a left-over initramfs after the kernel package has been removed.

To test this, you could prepare a patch that includes at least one out-of-tree device driver and the kernel. You would install the patch, reboot the system into the new kernel, and then remove the patch while running the new kernel. After the patch is removed, if there is a left-over initramfs in /boot, then we would have this problem.

Again, I am not sure if this problem really exists! It is possible that the initramfs will be removed anyway, because it is a part of the kernel-core package being uninstalled, after all.

To fix the left-over initramfs issue. we will not regenerate the initramfs if the patch includes kernel,  kernel upgrade will also generate initramfs.

Similar comment re: the list of directories and *PLUS* the following:

Some of these hooks are special, because the list of files that match the patterns will be provided to the standard input of the scriptlet. In the case of %transfiletriggerin, you need to empty the standard input using cat >/dev/null or something similar. (You could also check whether specific files have been updated using grep -q -e 'some_pattern', but this should not be necessary for our use case, I think.)

Please see the documentation at: https://rpm-software-management.github.io/rpm/manual/file_triggers.html

(Note that the %transfiletriggerpostun above is extra special, and it is not provided with a list of files, as noted in the reference: 

```
%transfiletriggerpostun: Executed once after transaction for all
uninstalled packages that contained file(s) that matches prefix
of this trigger. Note: the list of triggering files is not available
in this trigger type.
```
)

Hi Jiping,

Ah, I think we are having a communication issue. Let me help out.

In more practical terms, my suggestions result in something like this:

```
%transfiletriggerpostun -- /lib/modules/%{KVERREL}%{?1:+%{1}}

# No file list is provided via standard input, according to the
# documentation, so we do not need to flush standard input.

echo "Updating initramfs with dracut..."
if dracut --force ; then
       echo "Successfully updated initramfs."
else
       echo "Failed to update initramfs."
       echo "You must update your initramfs image for changes to take place."
       exit -1
fi

%transfiletriggerin -- /lib/modules/%{KVERREL}%{?1:+%{1}}

# Need to flush the standard input, because a list of files that caused
# this trigger to fire is provided by RPM via standard input. If needed,
# we can check if there are specific files we are interested in and only
# re-generate initramfs in that case, but in our use case, this is not
# necessary -- we always want to regenerate the initramfs.
#
# Example 1: Only regenerate dracut if ice.ko is in the list:
#
#   if ! grep -q -e '/ice\.ko'; then
#     exit 0
#   fi
#
# Example 2: dump the list of files that caused this trigger to fire,
#            via standard error:
#
#   cat 1>&2

# Regardless of which files fire the trigger, we would like to regenerate
# the initramfs, so flush the standard input.
cat >/dev/null

echo "Updating initramfs with dracut..."
if dracut --force ; then
        echo "Successfully updated initramfs."
else
        echo "Failed to update initramfs."
        echo "You must update your initramfs image for changes to take place."
        exit -1
fi
```

Could you test this, please?

Thank you,

Vefa

Kernel installations/upgrades/removals will be handled by the /bin/kernel-install calls in %posttrans and %preun, so those are covered, because /bin/kernel-install will call new-kernel-pkg which in turn calls dracut to regenerate the initramfs, if I remember correctly.

Regenerating the initramfs for other packages (such as out-of-tree kernel modules) will only be carried out by the %transfiletriggerin scriptlet of the kernel RPM package corresponding to the currently running kernel.

I think that this is reasonable, because StarlingX always changes the kernel version or revision when installing or removing a kernel patch. Looks good to me.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I guess I could have elaborated more on why I thought it was better.

The straightforward monkey patching doesn't work at all for some pretty important parts of moto, so we had patching happening at test setup, and patching happening after the provider was already started.  This caused race conditions where the test might actually try to talk to AWS instead of using fakes.

I think the new system is helpful because it actually lets us set up fakes and mocks reliably, and we do all of it the same way so that it's consistent (no worrying about where in the startup sequence we're performing the patch).

Finally, the decorator approach is consistent with some improvements we've made in zuul (eg simple_layout) and is fairly common in testing frameworks.  I think it's good that we can set parameters for the "outside world" like what AWS's fake quota is for us outside the test methods.

I'm not sure I agree that it is simpler and more readable. There is a lot of indirection between test functions and test classes and plumbing attributes through to each individual test run. In the past it was pretty straightforward monkey patching (that was a bit wordy), but now we're maintaining a lot of extra state on various objects to track what our patched state is.

Nit the test name and comment below don't seem to agree on what is being tested.

In this case I think what we are doing is testing a min ready request to aws which happens to be a tenant less request. Could probably update the comment to be a bit more explicit about that.
I agree it could be clarified (but I don't think it's wrong).  The min-ready pseudo-request may behave much differently (potentially not just due to lack of tenant info) than a "real" node request.

Let me know what you find on the route advertisement question, then I can re-vote.

So I have refactored the code because of this question.

I have found a way to get the "owner" of a network resource (route or rule), the "proto" of the resource indicates if the object was created by the kernel (ex a default route when configuring an ip address), by keepalived, by router-advertisement, or by sn admin (which, in the amphora, is Octavia).
So in patchset 15 we are only updating/deleting resources that we own, we cannot delete a route announced by ra (or keepalived), the code is way simpler than in the previous patchsets.

The only resource that cannot be 'tagged' with an owner is the address.
So I have renamed the unclear "ignore" flag, it is now "octavia_owned".
Ignore means that an address was potentially configured by keepalived and our tool should not have tried to add/delete it.
Now, if octavia_owned is True it means that the address should be configured by amphora-interface, if it is False it means that this address could be configured by keepalived and should not be considered as a removable address.
THis does look better. Just one question about a debug log line.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I agree with Elod, I have started to wrote the same comment but he was faster than me.

I see that this patch modifies the code in order to make it work with SQLAlchemy 1.4 version in stable/wallaby. For the record, in stable/wallaby the upper constraint of SQLAlchemy is 1.3.23 [1]. My question is: are these backports backward compatible? so that they work with SQLAlchemy 1.3.23? If not, then we should not release this. (In fact, the patches should be reverted as in that case they are against stable policy). Giving -1 for now, to highlight my question.


[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/commit/fa7c262ee118ffcee36df68a518b18b094ec207d/upper-constraints.txt#L152

If that is compatible, then I'm OK with it. (Note, that this kind of patches are more like downstream fixes and not the best for stable branches, as CentOS 9 was not amongst the supported distros [1] at release time, and for stable branches mostly bugfix backports can be merged, and this is clearly not a bug fix. Though I understand that RH needs this for CentOS 9 Stream...)

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html

@Elod, @Daniel yes that's a compatibility patch to get stable/wallaby work with sqlalchemy 1.4(the one shipped with CentOS 9-Stream). The patch works fine with both sqlalchemy 1.3 and 1.4. There are comments confirming backward compatibility in patch itself https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.db/+/852097.

Great catch! I'm was checking as this was working for us and want to know how/why.

What happens is that we were using the default (br-ex) for the flat provider network. And the extra one (br-vlan) was used for the provider networks and it does not need the arp/ndp enabled (that config is used by tripleo-ansible to set that) but the vlan device we connect to the bridge. So, not sure if the best option is to fix it in here, or remove the need for this option and allow the ovn-bgp-agent to detect and set ip up itself. Adding -1 to ensure discussion, but the patch LGTM
probably a simpler solution is to drop that parameter as proposed in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/854959

Yes, I updated the text to better state this. I'm open to suggestions here. The intention is that there can be firewall rules that cannot be modified/removed by a tenant. In other words, an Openstack administrator should be able to enforce a set of rules for all tenants, without fear that a tenant could circumvent that security.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: nit: I think a segment ID is not a list and [] sounds tricky as the default value.

Ahh, that made me test that when, for example, the network is flat. The segment retrieved has tag=None. That throws the following error: 
ERROR ovsdbapp.backend.ovs_idl.vlog [-] attempting to write bad value to column tag (ovsdb error: expected integer, got <class 'NoneType'>): ovs.db.error.Error: ovsdb error: expected integer, got <class 'NoneType'>


You should change that to:
  # That should cover if seg_id=0, although I don't now when that could
  # be possible.
  tag = segment.get(segment_def.SEGMENTATION_ID)
  tag = tag if tag is not None else []
That's interesting! Testing for testing this. I thought get() would always return the default value (in this case []) when SEGMENTATION_ID was None

Yeah, it looks strange but in the OVN database when there is no tag it's represented as an empty array. For example:

stack@central:~/devstack$ sudo ovn-nbctl list logical_switch_port | grep "tag "
tag                 : []
tag                 : []
tag                 : 3505
tag                 : []
tag                 : 144

neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py.message: When I implemented this feature, I assumed all mech_driver were going to be "AgentMechanismDriverBase". For OVN this is not the case. "OVNMechanismDriver" inherits directly from "api.MechanismDriver" ...
... that means OVN mech driver won't have "agent_type" ...

... and we can't retrieve the supported VIF types from this method.

For OVN we need to implement a "get_supported_vif_type" without passing the agent. I guess (you'll have more knowledge about this than me) that the VIF type will depend on the chassis. So we need a method, implemented in "api.MechanismDriver" (without input argments) that returns the list of supported VIFs.

In "api.MechanismDriver", this method should return an empty list (by default).

In the OVN mech driver, if I'm not wrong, should list all chassis, check the datapath type (netdev, system) and return the corresponding VIF type (VIF_TYPE_OVS, VIF_TYPE_VHOST_USER)
+1 to this, in a follow up patch.
Cool, yeah I will put it as a follow-up patch then. We would need to wait for a neutron-lib release too before using it here

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The fix looks right but the explanation is not correct. It is not due to the implementation of __getattr__ but calling hasattr inside of __getattr__
If you look at the python documentation, hasattr internally calls getattr which will call __getattribute__ raising AttributeNotFound and calling __getattr__ which again calls hasattr and the loop goes on.

We can also see the same in the log trace in launchpad bug:
2021-06-11 18:35:08.474 1489245 ERROR cinder.cmd.volume File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py", line 385, in __getattr__
2021-06-11 18:35:08.474 1489245 ERROR cinder.cmd.volume if hasattr(self.target_driver, attr):
2021-06-11 18:35:08.474 1489245 ERROR cinder.cmd.volume File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py", line 2937, in __getattr__
2021-06-11 18:35:08.474 1489245 ERROR cinder.cmd.volume if hasattr(self.sf_driver, attr):

notice __getattr__ calls hasattr which again calls __getattr__ calling hasattr and so on...
nit: in
Done

there were two __getattr__, one inside SolidFireDriver class [0] and the other one in SolidFireISCSI class [1].

SolidFireDriver getattr checks if SolidFireISCSI has the attribute with hasattr which triggers SolidFireISCSI getattr which also checks if SolidFireDriver has the attribute with hasattr, and so on.

what I did was remove one of them and fix the statements that depend on it.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py#L403

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py#L3006

If IOBase is closed then the first call won't do anything and rbd_image is always closed after the IOBase is closed.
Ack, thanks for the the detailed explanation!

Sorry, I don't follow.  As far as I can see there is no redundancy that can be avoided.

The fact that the base method also checks "if closed" doesn't help us avoid calling "self.rbd_image.close()" multiple times.

We cannot write:

  super().close()
  if not self.closed:
      self.rbd_image.close()

Because in that code the if will always evaluate to False (parent class close sets closed to True).

And changing the order is no good either:

  if not self.closed:
      self.rbd_image.close()
  super().close()

Because the parent's class close will call flush, which shouldn't be called on a closed file.  Which reminds me that we should also call parent's method on flush to fail if file is already closed.  Will update this patch.

And the parent's implementation on its own is not sufficient because it doesn't call self.rbd_image.close.

What that doc is saying is that the base implementation's close can be called multiple times and it won't return an error.

Which is exactly what our close on the IOWrapper does now, it has no effect if it's already closed.

If I remember correctly, even if self.closed is True this method will be called by the finalizer on garbage collection.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: FWIW, it's removing the catch_warnings context that's the big win.

Few data points using a large (~5900 shard) DB -- first, py2 before the patch:

 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' 'json.loads(d)'
 10 loops, best of 3: 44 msec per loop
 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; from swift.common.utils import ShardRange; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' '[ShardRange.from_dict(x) for x in json.loads(d)]'
 10 loops, best of 3: 217 msec per loop

And after:

 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' 'json.loads(d)'
 10 loops, best of 3: 43.5 msec per loop
 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; from swift.common.utils import ShardRange; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' '[ShardRange.from_dict(x) for x in json.loads(d)]'
 10 loops, best of 3: 167 msec per loop

So like a 25% speed up -- not bad! Let's switch to py37, though. Before:

 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' 'json.loads(d)'
 20 loops, best of 5: 18.8 msec per loop
 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; from swift.common.utils import ShardRange; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' '[ShardRange.from_dict(x) for x in json.loads(d)]'
 2 loops, best of 5: 147 msec per loop

After:

 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' 'json.loads(d)'
 20 loops, best of 5: 18.2 msec per loop
 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; from swift.common.utils import ShardRange; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' '[ShardRange.from_dict(x) for x in json.loads(d)]'
 2 loops, best of 5: 99.9 msec per loop

With py39, it gets *even better*. Before:

 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' 'json.loads(d)'
 20 loops, best of 5: 16.7 msec per loop
 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; from swift.common.utils import ShardRange; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' '[ShardRange.from_dict(x) for x in json.loads(d)]'
 2 loops, best of 5: 114 msec per loop

After:

 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' 'json.loads(d)'
 20 loops, best of 5: 16.5 msec per loop
 ++ python -m timeit -s 'import json; from swift.common.utils import ShardRange; d=open("nvetl-data-prod.shards.json").read()' '[ShardRange.from_dict(x) for x in json.loads(d)]'
 5 loops, best of 5: 78.6 msec per loop

So, this patch brings a 25-45% improvement within any given python version, and upgrading python can *separately* bring like a 50% improvement!

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
This code can be refactored to remove duplication and be more readable. You basically remove 2 lines for Debian OS pertaining to nslcd and nscd.
Please explain why secure openldap config is triggered here.

As you can see, what the "platform::ldap::secure::config" class does is:
- create openldap-cert.crt and openldap-cert.key files
- modify openldap configuration to use the certificate and key files by:
 (command => "ldapmodify -D ${dn} -w \"${admin_pw}\" -xH ldap:/// -f ${slapd_etc_path}/certs.ldif")
 
In current implementation, the above is triggered by cert-mon after controller is unlocked. As described in the commit message, cert-mon could trigger the above operation before controller-1 is installed, causing openldap certificate never generated on controller-1.

Since the unlock puppet manifest will be applied on both controllers, triggering the above operation during unlock will guarantee openldap certificate and key files are generated on controller-1.
So the secure openldap configuration is done with the start of the slapd service.
Seems like the cert and key are being passed here as parameters. Where are those parameters coming from?
Ack
I think you probably need to add a depends-on here then to point to that change
Depends-on to config
See my reply to commit message.
The cert and key come from platform::ldap::params::secure_cert and platform::ldap::params::secure_key, which in turn come from puppet hieradata secure_system.yaml(generated by sysinv puppet plugin).
Why did you choose to refactor the previous code that was working and had less footprint? I find redundant setting for mode in this implementation.

Since with the current implementation, secure openldap won't have certificate and key files when controller-1 becomes active controller, so sssd won't be able to connect to secure openldap (no certificate error).
Ack
you would restart slapd service, not sssd.

Are we talking here about openldap certificate and key? The sssd.conf contains the ca certificate from /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt. If the ca cert does not change we do not need to restart sssd service.
Done

As you mentioned before (and verified by test), secure openldap doesn't need to restart here. But since the certificate and key are changed (triggered by certificate renewal), sssd will lose connection to secure openldap (since openldap is using new certificate). That's why the sssd needs to be restart here to reconnect.
You are right. I'm testing to verify that the restart is not needed. Will update the change after that.

see:
